fields.description: System must implement non-layered picokernel architecture where services plug directly into kernel core.
ThreadX must be written primarily in ANSI C with minimal processor-specific assembly language.
System must require 2-20KB ROM and 1-2KB RAM with automatic scaling based on used services.
ThreadX must achieve sub-microsecond context switching on popular processors with deterministic performance.
System must support priority-based preemptive scheduling with 32-1024 configurable priority levels.
ThreadX must implement unique preemption-threshold scheduling to reduce context switches.
System must provide threads, mutexes, semaphores, event flags, message queues, and memory pools.
Mutex implementation must support priority inheritance to prevent priority inversion scenarios.
System must provide both block pools for fixed-size and byte pools for variable-size memory allocation.
ThreadX requires periodic timer interrupt source for timeout, time-slicing, and application timer services.
System must boot in fewer than 120 cycles with optimized initialization sequence.
ISR processing must save only scratch registers unless preemption is required.
Core API services must execute in 0.2-0.6 microseconds on typical 200MHz processors.
ThreadX must be certified for IEC 61508 SIL 4, UL standards, and TÃœV safety requirements.
Code must comply with all required and mandatory rules of MISRA-C:2004 and MISRA-C:2012.
tx_kernel_enter function must never return and transition directly to thread scheduling loop.
tx_application_define function must be provided to create initial system resources.
System must support extensive build-time configuration through TX_* defines and tx_user.h file.
TX_DISABLE_ERROR_CHECKING must allow bypassing parameter validation for performance optimization.
TX_ENABLE_STACK_CHECKING must provide runtime stack overflow detection and analysis.
Threads must support initialization, ready, suspended, terminated, and completed states.
All blocking operations must support TX_NO_WAIT, TX_WAIT_FOREVER, and specific timeout values.
Event flags must support 32-bit groups with AND, OR, AND_CLEAR, and OR_CLEAR operations.
Message queues must support configurable message sizes of 1, 2, 4, 8, or 16 ULONGs.
TX_TIMER_TICKS_PER_SECOND must define timer resolution with default of 100 for 10ms intervals.
ThreadX SMP must perform dynamic load balancing across N processors with core affinity control.
ThreadX Modules must provide memory protection through separate address spaces with MPU/MMU support.
System must track thread resumptions, suspensions, preemptions, and priority inversions for analysis.
TX_ENABLE_EVENT_TRACE must capture system events for TraceX analysis tool integration.
System must support application-specific notify callback registration for ThreadX objects.
ThreadX must be completely endian-neutral with wide processor family support through tx_port.h.
ThreadX must support major embedded development toolchains with comprehensive kernel awareness.
All public APIs must follow tx_object_operation naming convention with consistent return values.
All APIs must return TX_SUCCESS on success or specific error codes with comprehensive coverage.
ThreadX must define portable data types (UINT, ULONG, VOID, CHAR) mapping to compiler types.
System must support flexible memory placement with instruction, constant, data, and stack areas.
Initialization must follow reset vector, development tool init, main function, then kernel entry sequence.
tx_initialize_low_level must configure timer interrupts, exception vectors, and memory initialization.
Each ThreadX port must include demo_threadx.c demonstration application for validation.
ThreadX must provide complete C source code and processor-specific assembly for transparency.
System must provide _tx_version_id string and _tx_build_options variable for version tracking.
ThreadX must support both preemptive and cooperative scheduling modes for thread execution.
System must support configurable time-slicing for round-robin scheduling within priority levels.
ThreadX must support unlimited runtime creation and deletion of system objects.
System must maintain separate interrupt stack to prevent corruption of thread stacks.
ThreadX must provide runtime stack analysis to track usage and detect overflow conditions.
System must provide optimized timer interrupt processing with configurable ISR vs thread processing.
ThreadX must support Windows and Linux development hosts with ~1MB source code footprint.
System must support JTAG, BDM, and ICE debug connections with minimal target intrusion.
ThreadX must provide adaptation layers for FreeRTOS, POSIX, and OSEK API compatibility.
Kernel must follow strict initialization order: low-level setup, high-level initialization, application define, then scheduler entry.
The _tx_initialize_kernel_enter function must never return and directly transition to scheduler loop.
System must support configurable priority levels with TX_MAX_PRIORITIES as multiple of 32.
Threads must support READY (0), COMPLETED (1), TERMINATED (2), and additional suspension states.
Each thread must have configurable preemption threshold separate from priority level.
Threads must support configurable time-slice values for round-robin scheduling within same priority.
Thread creation must support AUTO_START and DONT_START options for immediate execution control.
System must provide dynamic memory allocation through byte pools with variable-size block allocation.
System must support fixed-size block pools for fast, deterministic memory allocation.
All memory allocations must maintain proper alignment based on TX_ALIGN_TYPE requirements.
Mutexes must support optional priority inheritance to prevent priority inversion.
Event flags must support AND/OR operations with optional clearing (TX_AND, TX_OR, TX_AND_CLEAR, TX_OR_CLEAR).
Queues must support configurable message sizes (1, 2, 4, 8, 16 ULONGs).
Semaphores must support counting with configurable initial and maximum values.
System must return specific error codes (TX_POOL_ERROR, TX_PTR_ERROR, TX_SIZE_ERROR, etc.).
All API functions must have corresponding txe_ error-checking variants.
Optional TX_SAFETY_CRITICAL mode must provide exception handling for critical failures.
Optional TX_ENABLE_STACK_CHECKING must detect stack corruption during execution.
Optional TX_EXECUTION_PROFILE_ENABLE must track thread execution statistics.
Optional TX_ENABLE_RANDOM_NUMBER_STACK_FILLING must fill stacks with random patterns for debugging.
All blocking operations must support TX_NO_WAIT (0) for immediate return.
All blocking operations must support TX_WAIT_FOREVER (0xFFFFFFFF) for indefinite blocking.
All blocking operations must support arbitrary timeout values in timer ticks.
All kernel operations must be safe for execution from interrupt service routines.
Kernel must maintain global system state to prevent invalid operations (initialization vs. running).
System must detect and prevent invalid operations from wrong execution context.
Optional TX_ENABLE_EVENT_TRACE must record all kernel operations for analysis.
System must allow user-defined trace events through tx_trace_user_event_insert.
Optional performance monitoring must track timing and resource usage statistics.
System must support extensive compile-time configuration through TX_* defines.
tx_user.h must override default configuration parameters.
TX_PORT_SPECIFIC_DATA must allow architecture-specific additions.
Module manager must support runtime loading of separately compiled applications.
Each module must have isolated memory space and controlled kernel access.
System must support module loading, starting, stopping, and unloading operations.
Kernel must create dedicated timer thread with highest priority for timer processing.
System must support user-created timers with one-shot and periodic modes.
Timer interrupts must be processed either in ISR or dedicated timer thread context.
All public APIs must follow tx_object_operation naming pattern.
All APIs must return TX_SUCCESS (0) on success or specific error code on failure.
